conversation.content: [anxious] Okay, so we've got a serious problem here. [clearing throat] I'm down in the sub-basement right now and the foundation is— [pause] it's bad. [stern] Really, really bad. Like, I've been doing this for fifteen years and I've never seen cracks this wide. [frustrated] We're talking structural failure level damage here, not just some settling. You can actually see daylight through some of these gaps. [very quietly] That shouldn't be possible. [speeding up] The whole north wall is basically separating from the footer, there's water seepage everywhere, and the support columns are, um... they're showing stress fractures. [shaky voice] I don't want to be dramatic but this building could— [pause] I mean, we need everyone out. [loudly] Now. [apologetic] I know that sounds extreme but I'm looking at what could be catastrophic failure. [angry] And you know what? We flagged issues six months ago! [bitter] But nobody wanted to spend the money for a proper inspection. [sigh] Well, now we're way past inspection territory. [urgently] This is, uh, this is evacuation territory. [very sincerely] I'm not trying to scare anyone, but I have a responsibility here. [confidently] We need structural engineers, we need the fire department, and we need to clear this building immediately. [hesitantly] I just... I really hope I'm overreacting, but I don't think I am.

subject: Your maintenance crew reporting that the building's foundation is critically damaged
